page.title: 10THE BLUE BELL HOTEL
page.content: The Blue Bell Hotel is 33 years old but the building dates back to l690 when it was the vicarage and you can still see a doorway in a part of the dining room where the vicar used to get out of the house and go to church. After it had been the vicarage it was called the Heversham Hotel. A new bypass was built in l937 which allowed more people to come to the Blue Bell. There is a hole beneath the bar floor which dates back to the day's of Oliver Crommwell where church silver valuables were kept from the King's men. The hole cost 5p. or a shilling in those days to dig. After it was called the Bell until it was painted blue and from then on it was called Blue Bell. Today it is quite modern and you can still see a couple of faint words from Heversham Hotel which haven't been rubbed off by the paint.
